abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though the
            institutional development impact was negligible. Lessons
            highlight the following. The project illustrates well that
            institutional, and financial improvements are far more
            difficult to achieve than civil works; thus, project design
            should carefully consider the risks of financing, e.g.,
            hardware and software as in this case, to avoid regretting
            high financial costs, and rather choose to abandon
            financially risky components. Particularly in middle-income
            countries, Bank funding is expensive and not competitive,
            where lower financing costs were found by the Government.
            Therefore, the Bank must carefully evaluate the proxies put
            forward to represent government commitment, because multiple
            performance contracts were relied upon by the Bank to
            achieve key policy objectives. However, the contracts were
            not respected, and the Bank had little recourse during
            implementation - short of suspension, which was not the
            option, considering the progress being made in social
            connections. Moreover, in light of too many implementing
            agencies, ministries, and components, coordination efforts
            were dissipated, which reinforces the need for an
            established open competitive bidding to prod private sector
            participation, rather than direct negotiation.
